instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
This board seem to be not liquide damage. No magsafe or magsafe only with chines adapters.
PPBUS - 12.26V

<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 0V
Checked <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> and arround is ok, no missing or corroded resistors/traces. VIN to pin 1,3 at 3.3V

Next to check?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Either bad <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>, crap under SMC or dead SMC. You did check <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR>?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>
